etymologies: mid 17th century; earliest use found in Samuel Pepys (1633–1703), naval official and diarist. From French angélique kind of lute, South American leguminous tree native to Guyana, ultimately specific uses as noun of angélique

definitions: A plucked stringed instrument of the baroque period, resembling a lute or theorbo in form, having a round back and a long neck with two pegboxes, the lower having ten single strings and the upper having six or seven. Compare angel lute, angelot.
A hardwood derived from tropical South American leguminous trees of the genus Dicorynia, which is highly resistant to decay and used in carpentry, construction, and shipbuilding.
